title: GSP Stadium
text:
Gymnastic Club "The Pancyprians" Stadium (GSP Stadium) () is a <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="stadium">stadium</a> in <a href="Strovolos">Strovolos</a>, <a href="Nicosia%20District">Nicosia District</a>, <a href="Cyprus">Cyprus</a>. Although small by international standards, it is the largest stadium in Cyprus, with a capacity of 22,859 and was opened in 1999. It serves as the home stadium for the 3 biggest clubs of Nicosia <a href="APOEL%20FC">APOEL</a>, Olympiakos & <a href="AC%20Omonia">Omonia</a> . It is also the home stadium of the <a href="Cyprus%20national%20football%20team">Cyprus national football team</a>. A stadium under the same name, the <a href="GSP%20Stadium%20%281902%29">old GSP Stadium</a>, existed from 1902 until 1999 in the centre of Nicosia and had a capacity of 12,000.
History.
Designed by Theo. David Architects, the new GSP Stadium opened for use on 6 October 1999. The complex has three arenas: a football stadium, an athletics stadium and an auxiliary football pitch intended for training. The stadium is owned by the <a href="Pancyprian%20Gymnastic%20Association">Pancyprian Gymnastic Association</a>. With an official <a href="seating%20capacity">seating capacity</a> of 22,859 the new GSP is the largest football venue in Cyprus. It is located at the entrance to Nicosia (as approached from the <a href="A1%20motorway%20%28Cyprus%29">A1 highway</a>) and was inaugurated in 1999 by the then-President <a href="Glafcos%20Clerides">Glafcos Clerides</a> and <a href="Archbishop%20Chrysostomos%20I">Archbishop Chrysostomos I</a>. The first game was held on 6 October 1999 and there was a friendly match between <a href="APOEL%20FC">APOEL</a> and <a href="AC%20Omonia">Omonia</a>, which ended 3–3.
Since then, the stadium is not only the home of Nicosian teams but usually of Cyprus national football team. During the <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28UEFA%29">World Cup 2006 qualifying round</a> it was used as home for all matches of Cyprus. The stadium is the only one in Cyprus which satisfies UEFA Criteria. For this reason since 2004 it is used as home for all the teams of Cyprus in European Cups. Annually, the stadium hosts the <a href="Cypriot%20Super%20Cup">Cypriot Super Cup</a>. Also until 2005, it was hosting annually the <a href="Cypriot%20Cup">Cypriot Cup</a> final.
In 2002, the stadium was home for <a href="Israel">Israel</a>i clubs for the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> and <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> matches. It hosted the <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> quarter final (as home for Hapoel Tel Aviv) between <a href="Hapoel%20Tel%20Aviv%20FC">Hapoel Tel Aviv</a> and <a href="A.C.%20Milan">A.C. Milan</a>. It was also used by <a href="Maccabi%20Haifa%20F.C.">Maccabi Haifa</a> for home stadium for the <a href="2002%E2%80%9303%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20group%20stage">2002–03 UEFA Champions League group stage</a> matches and for the <a href="2002%E2%80%9303%20UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> matches. Some matches were attractive for Cypriots like the matches Maccabi Haifa-<a href="Olympiacos%20F.C.">Olympiacos CFP</a> and Maccabi Haifa-<a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a>, since those two Maccabi's rivals are very popular in Cyprus.
It's the only stadium in Cyprus build only for track & field games. In addition with the hotel, it provides a full training centre solution for athletes all over the world. During the <a href="2004%20Summer%20Olympics">Athens 2004 Olympic Games</a>, many athletes from different countries used the stadium for training. In 2001, Bruno Zauli took place here with great success.
The GSP Stadium hosted all home matches of <a href="Anorthosis%20Famagusta%20FC">Anorthosis Famagusta's</a> <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2008–09 UEFA Champions League</a> <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20group%20stage">group stage</a> campaign and all <a href="APOEL%20FC">APOEL's</a> <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2009–10 UEFA Champions League</a> <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20group%20stage">group stage</a> home matches. Two years later, it hosted all APOEL's home matches in the club's surprising run to the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20knockout%20phase%23Quarter-finals">quarter-finals</a> of the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2011–12 UEFA Champions League</a>. Also, it hosted again all APOEL's home matches in their third participation in the <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2014–15 UEFA Champions League</a> <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20group%20stage">group stages</a>. All matches were sold out by APOEL's fans.
GSP Stadium also hosted <a href="AEK%20Larnaca%20F.C.">AEK Larnaca</a>'s <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2011–12 UEFA Europa League</a> <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20group%20stage">group stage</a> matches, <a href="AEL%20Limassol">AEL Limassol</a>'s <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2012–13 UEFA Europa League</a> <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20group%20stage">group stage</a> matches, <a href="APOEL%20FC">APOEL</a>'s and <a href="Apollon%20Limassol">Apollon Limassol</a>'s <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2013–14 UEFA Europa League</a> <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20group%20stage">group stage</a> matches, Apollon's <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2014–15 UEFA Europa League</a> <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20group%20stage">group stage</a> matches and APOEL's <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20group%20stage">2015–16</a> group stage matches. GSP Stadium also hosted all APOEL's home matches in the club's impressive run to the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20knockout%20phase%23Round%20of%2016">last 16</a> of the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2016–17 UEFA Europa League</a>.
Due to <a href="February%202014%20Euromaidan%20riots">riots in Kiev</a> and after <a href="UEFA">UEFA</a>'s decision, GSP Stadium hosted the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2013–14 UEFA Europa League</a> <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20knockout%20phase%23Round%20of%2032">round of 32</a> match between <a href="FC%20Dynamo%20Kyiv">Dynamo Kyiv</a> and <a href="Valencia%20CF">Valencia CF</a> on 20 February 2014, which ended in 0–2 Valencia win.
In the 2016–17 domestic league season, tenants <a href="APOEL">APOEL</a> drew the highest average home attendance (7,126).
Average attendances.
The all-time attendance record for the football stadium is 23,043 tickets in the match between <a href="APOEL%20FC">APOEL</a> and <a href="AC%20Omonia">Omonia</a> for the <a href="2002%E2%80%9303%20Cypriot%20First%20Division">2002–03 Cypriot First Division</a>. The match was held on 7 December 2002 and ended in a goalless draw.
The record of the highest attendance for a <a href="UEFA">European Competition</a> game is 22,701 tickets in the match between <a href="APOEL%20FC">APOEL</a> and <a href="Olympique%20Lyonnais">Olympique Lyonnais</a> for the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20knockout%20phase%23Round%20of%2016">2011–12 UEFA Champions League last-16</a>. The match was held on 7 March 2012 and ended with a 1–0 win for APOEL after extra time and 4–3 win on penalties.
Source: <a href="https%3A//www.webcitation.org/69STDvmxq%3Furl%3Dhttp%3A//www.european-football-statistics.co.uk/attn/2000/avecyp.htm">European Football Statistics</a>
Attributes.
GSP Athletic Centre includes.
GSP Football Stadium
Outdoors and yet covered, the Stadium Square offers the best of both worlds, for large-scale activities of any kind. Located between the football stadium and the track and field stadium, this vast space provides maximum flexibility, as it can be furnished and equipped, decorated or divided as required for each event. Providing ample space for activities, catering and live DJ events – with or without paid entrance facilities – the Stadium square lends itself to:
GSP Track and Field Stadium
Includes :
Allegra GSP Sports Center
Hotel which includes:
The Club.
The Gymnastic Association "Pancypria" was founded in 1894 with the initiative of the lawyer Theofanis Theodotou and the doctors Antonios Theodotou and Aristofanis Fenievs.
Excellent athletes of GSP who won significant victories not only in Cyprus but abroad as well, brightened this stadium with their presence. GSP was linked with classic athletes of the capital and became the expresser (spirit) of the track and field.
In 1896, the G.S. Pancypria participated in the A' Pancyprian Games which took place in the G.S. Olympia Stadium in <a href="Limassol">Limassol</a>. Since then it has participated in all pancyprian games because the Pancyprian Games became a significant national feast for Cyprus, during which the stadium, where the games were taking place, was decorated with Greek flags and the national desires were proclaimed .
The athletes of GSP were declared winners of the Pancyprian Games and other games that took place in Cyprus, many times. Many of them were qualified periodically and sent abroad where they accomplished great victories.
